**Massachusetts General Laws (G.L.) c. 1.proposition: The Plaintiff, Jessica Greene, brings this action against her landlord, Defendant Mark Thompson, for breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment as provided by **Massachusetts General Laws (G.L.) c. 186, § 14**.

**G.L. c. 218, \u00a7 19**.proposition: This Court has jurisdiction pursuant to **G.L. c. 218, § 19** and **G.L. c. 186, § 14**, as the damages sought are within the jurisdictional limit of the Springfield District Court.

**G.L. c. 223, \u00a7 2**.proposition: Venue is proper in this Court under **G.L. c. 223, § 2** because the events giving rise to this action occurred at 456 Maple Street, Springfield, Massachusetts, which is located in this Court’s district.

**Al-Ziab v. Mourgis**, 424 Mass. 847 (1.proposition: Massachusetts law holds that a complete lack of repair or failure to rectify conditions materially interfering with a tenant’s use of the premises constitutes a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment.
**Al-Ziab v. Mourgis**, 424 Mass. 847 (1.support_reasoning: The case directly explains that under G.L. c. 186, § 14 a landlord’s negligent failure to repair known defects that interfere with the tenant’s use of the premises constitutes a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment. In doing so, it cites prior cases where failures to repair conditions rendering premises uninhabitable or materially defective (e.g., leaky roof, failure to bring and keep apartment in habitable condition) were held to violate § 14. Thus, it affirms that a complete lack of repair or failure to rectify materially interfering conditions can breach quiet enjoyment, provided there is at least negligence and notice.
**Al-Ziab v. Mourgis**, 424 Mass. 847 (1.relevant_excerpt: We noted that a landlord’s failure “to repair defects of which he has notice in leased premises is an omission which frequently has been deemed to violate § 14.” See Cruz, supra at 789, citing Simon v. Solomon, supra at 103 (failure to control floods in tenant’s apartment); Darmetko v. Boston Hous. Auth., 378 Mass. 758, 761 (1979) (failure to repair leaky roof); Dorgan v. Loukas, 19 Mass. App. Ct. 959, 960 (1985) (failure to bring apartment into habitable condition and keep it so). Today we make clear what was implicit in those rulings: to support the imposition of liability under the quiet enjoyment statute, there must be a showing of at least negligent conduct by a landlord….

**Dartmouth v. Silva**, 32 Mass. App. Ct.proposition: Massachusetts law holds that a complete lack of repair or failure to rectify conditions materially interfering with a tenant’s use of the premises constitutes a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment.
**Dartmouth v. Silva**, 32 Mass. App. Ct.support_reasoning: The opinion in Dartmouth v. Silva is about wrongful/illegal eviction under G.L. c. 186, § 14 (eviction by force without judicial process), negligence, conversion, damages, and c. 93A instructions. It does not discuss a landlord’s failure to repair, conditions interfering with use, or the covenant of quiet enjoyment as a matter of Massachusetts law. Because the case never addresses repair obligations or quiet enjoyment, it cannot be authority for the stated proposition.
**Dartmouth v. Silva**, 32 Mass. App. Ct.relevant_excerpt: General Laws c. 186, § 14 (1986 ed.), states in pertinent part: “Any lessor or landlord of any building . . . occupied for dwelling purposes . . . who attempts to regain possession of such premises by force without benefit of judicial process, shall be punished by a fine of not less than twenty-*205*five dollars nor more than three hundred dollars, or by imprisonment for not more than six months. Any person who commits any act in violation of this section shall also be liable for actual and consequential damages or three month’s rent, whichever is greater, and the costs of the action, including a reasonable attorney’s fee . . . .”

**Simon v. Solomon**, 385 Mass. 91 (1982.proposition: Defendant’s failure to make timely repairs has effectively evicted Plaintiff from part of her apartment, a violation of **G.L. c. 186, § 14**, which holds landlords strictly liable for breaches of the covenant of quiet enjoyment.
**Simon v. Solomon**, 385 Mass. 91 (1982.support_reasoning: The opinion does hold that the repeated flooding constituted an interference with the tenant’s quiet enjoyment under G.L. c. 186, § 14, but it does not frame this as a “constructive eviction from part of the apartment,” nor does it state that § 14 imposes strict liability for breaches of quiet enjoyment. The court instead emphasizes at least reckless conduct and discusses landlord fault and foreseeability, expressly noting that § 14’s liability is not absolute. Thus, the case supports liability under § 14 for reckless interference with quiet enjoyment, not strict-liability/constructive-partial-eviction as stated in the proposition.
**Simon v. Solomon**, 385 Mass. 91 (1982.relevant_excerpt: “Our analysis of the language and history of § 14, however, leads us to conclude that malicious intent is not necessary, and that the statute covers, at the least, reckless conduct such as Gem’s… When the Legislature chose the words ‘quiet enjoyment’ … it must have intended to incorporate these cases into the statute… Finally, Gem is liable to Solomon under § 14 because it violated its underlying duty to maintain sanitary conditions in her apartment, and thereby permitted repeated flooding to occur that interfered with her quiet enjoyment of her apartment.”
